title: Apply global dark background and eliminate white bleed-through across routes

requirements.summary: Apply the dark theme background token globally to html/body so any uncovered viewport area is dark instead of white.
acceptanceCriteria: On initial load (including before authentication), the visible page background is dark/black rather than white.
There is no white background visible around the app (e.g., page margins, overscroll area, or any region not covered by the routed page content).
The change is implemented via global styling (e.g., in frontend/src/index.css) using existing Tailwind tokens/classes (e.g., bg-background) so it remains consistent across all routes.

file_operations.description: Update the global base styles to apply the Tailwind theme token background to the document: set html and body to use bg-background (and text-foreground), ensure html/body have 100% height (or min-height) to cover the full viewport, and ensure the app mount container does not inherit a white background in any state (including before authentication).

requirements.summary: Adjust layout/background coverage so the dark background consistently fills the viewport and prevents white strips around fixed mobile navigation and short-content pages.
acceptanceCriteria: Landing, Connect, PTT, Activity, Settings, and About pages all show a consistent dark background even when the page content is shorter than the viewport height.
No white strip appears behind/around the fixed mobile bottom navigation or at the bottom of the page when scrolling.
The appâ€™s existing card/panel styling remains readable and unchanged except where strictly necessary to prevent white background bleed-through.

file_operations.description: Ensure the top-level layout wrapper provides continuous dark background coverage (e.g., apply bg-background to the outermost container, not just <main>), and adjust spacing/styling around the fixed mobile bottom navigation and footer so the dark background remains visible behind/around the nav (including safe-area inset handling where applicable) when content is short or during scroll/overscroll.
